title: Quality Planning & Assurance
description: Distinguish QA (defect prevention) from QC (defect detection) and master quality tools—Pareto Charts, Control Charts, Statistical Sampling.
objectives: Distinguish between Quality Assurance (defect prevention) and Quality Control (defect detection)
Select appropriate quality tool: Pareto Chart for prioritization, Control Chart for monitoring, Statistical Sampling for cost-effective inspection
Apply Rule of Seven to identify assignable causes in control charts
Understand Quality vs Grade and Accuracy vs Precision distinctions

screens.headline: Four Quality Crises. Seven Tools. Wrong Choice = $50K in Refunds

visual.description: Four crisis cards: portion scale (120g-180g variance), defect list (23 types), temperature chart (8 consecutive above mean), inspection queue (500 meals/day, 50 capacity). Jordan holds toolkit with 7 quality tools.

dialogue.text: Quality Assurance PREVENTS defects. Quality Control DETECTS them. Most PMs confuse the two—and pick the wrong tool for the job.

screens.learningHook: Savory's premium meal prep service ($18/meal) hit critical quality issues: portion inconsistency, 23 defect types, temperature anomaly, inspection bottleneck. Jordan has 7 tools: Pareto Chart, Control Chart, Check Sheet, Statistical Sampling, Six Sigma, Continuous Integration. Each solves a DIFFERENT problem. Match tool to problem, or risk catastrophic failures.

screens.title: Quality Tool Matching
screens.instructions: Match each quality problem to the correct tool. Each tool has a specific purpose—wrong tool wastes time on wrong problems.

scenarios.title: Portion Size Problem
description: Measurements are consistent with each other but far from target

questions.question: How would you describe these measurements?

feedback.correct: Perfect! Measurements are consistent (128g ± 4g = PRECISE), but far from 150g target (NOT ACCURATE). Systematic bias—portions consistently too small. Precision = consistency. Accuracy = close to target. Recalibrate scales to fix.
feedback.incorrect: Measurements cluster around 128g (± 4g) = PRECISE (consistent with each other). But target is 150g = NOT ACCURATE (far from target). Precision ≠ Accuracy. This is systematic calibration error.

scenarios.title: Defect Overload
description: 23 different defect types reported last month
Missing labels, wrong ingredients, leaking containers, incorrect portions, etc.
Jordan's team can only fix 5 root causes this quarter
Need to identify 'vital few' defects causing 80% of complaints

questions.question: Which quality tool should Jordan use?

feedback.correct: Excellent! Pareto Chart (80/20 rule) ranks defects by frequency, identifying vital few (20% of types) causing 80% of problems. Fix those first. Jordan already HAS the data—needs to PRIORITIZE.
feedback.incorrect: PARETO CHART applies 80/20 rule to prioritize which defects to fix first. Control Charts monitor stability (different purpose). Check Sheets COLLECT data (Jordan already has it). Statistical Sampling is for inspection (not prioritization).

scenarios.title: Temperature Anomaly
description: Prep station control chart: mean = 4°C, upper limit = 7°C, lower limit = 1°C
BUT all 8 are ABOVE the 4°C mean

options.text: Wait until reading exceeds upper limit (7°C)

feedback.correct: Perfect! Rule of Seven: 7+ consecutive measurements on one side of mean indicate assignable (non-random) cause. 8 consecutive above mean = investigate refrigeration unit BEFORE it exceeds 7°C and causes food safety issues. Rule of Seven catches problems EARLY.
feedback.incorrect: RULE OF SEVEN: 7 or more consecutive points on one side of mean = assignable cause requiring investigation, EVEN IF within limits. 8 consecutive above mean suggests refrigeration degrading. Investigate NOW, don't wait for limit breach.

scenarios.title: Inspection Bottleneck
description: Casey demands: 'Inspect EVERY meal before shipment' (500 meals/day)
Jordan's team can inspect 50 meals/day max
Need cost-effective approach ensuring quality without 100% inspection

options.text: Inspect only first 50 meals each morning

feedback.correct: Excellent! Statistical Sampling inspects representative subset (50 random meals/day = 10%) to predict overall quality. Cost-effective, statistically valid with proper RANDOM sampling. Hiring 10x inspectors costs $2M/year—unnecessary. Inspecting first 50 isn't statistically valid (quality drifts during day).
feedback.incorrect: STATISTICAL SAMPLING inspects representative subset (e.g., 50 random meals = 10%) to predict overall quality. Cost-effective and statistically valid when RANDOM. 100% inspection too expensive. First 50 meals not representative (quality can drift).

screens.title: Quality Assurance vs Quality Control Framework

qualityAssurance.definition: PREVENTING defects by improving processes, training, building quality in from start
qualityAssurance.cost: Higher upfront, lower long-term (fewer defects to fix)

qualityControl.definition: DETECTING defects through inspection, testing, measurement AFTER work completed
qualityControl.cost: Lower upfront, higher long-term (must fix defects found)

content.keyInsight: QA = Build it right the first time (prevention). QC = Catch defects before delivery (detection). Both necessary, but PMI emphasizes QA as more cost-effective.
content.pmbokRef: PMBOK 7th Edition: QA focuses on process improvement, QC focuses on deliverable verification

tools.name: Pareto Chart
tools.useWhen: Multiple defect types, need to focus limited resources
tools.example: 23 defect types → Pareto shows 3 cause 80% of complaints

tools.name: Control Chart
tools.useWhen: Track if process 'in control' (Rule of Seven: 7+ consecutive on one side)
tools.example: Temperature: 8 consecutive above mean → Investigate refrigeration

tools.name: Check Sheet
tools.useWhen: Need to gather raw data about frequency
tools.example: Kitchen staff mark tally for each defect type during shift

tools.name: Statistical Sampling
tools.purpose: Inspect subset to predict overall quality
tools.example: Inspect 50 random meals (10%) instead of all 500

tools.name: Six Sigma
tools.example: Premium service: <3.4 defective meals per million

tools.name: Continuous Integration
tools.useWhen: Software with frequent changes, need fast feedback
tools.example: Developers integrate daily, automated tests catch bugs immediately

accuracyVsPrecision.problem: Can be precise without being accurate = Systematic bias
accuracyVsPrecision.example: Portions all 128g ± 4g (PRECISE), but target 150g (NOT ACCURATE) = calibration error

qualityVsGrade.grade: Category or rank (high-end vs budget, luxury vs economy)
qualityVsGrade.quality: Meeting requirements and being fit for purpose
qualityVsGrade.distinction: Low grade is acceptable if meets requirements. Low quality is NEVER acceptable.
qualityVsGrade.example: Budget meal ($12, low grade) can be high quality. Premium meal ($18, high grade) with defects is low quality—UNACCEPTABLE.

ruleOfSeven.definition: 7 or more consecutive measurements on ONE side of mean = assignable cause
ruleOfSeven.whyItMatters: Catches problems BEFORE they breach control limits (early intervention)
ruleOfSeven.example: 8 consecutive temp readings above 4°C mean → Investigate clogged filter before temps exceed 7°C safe limit

applications.diagnosis: PRECISE (consistent 128g ± 4g) but NOT ACCURATE (far from 150g) = systematic bias
applications.solution: Recalibrate scales to 150g using reference weights

applications.finding: 3 defects (missing labels, wrong ingredients, leaking) = 78% of complaints
applications.solution: Fix those 3: label printer maintenance, ingredient checklist, better containers

applications.diagnosis: Rule of Seven triggered—refrigeration filter clogged
applications.solution: Replace filter, schedule preventive maintenance every 2 weeks
applications.result: Temps stabilized around 4°C mean with normal variation

applications.process: Random sample 50 meals (10%), calculate defect rate

high.text: Perfect! You didn't just memorize tools—you matched them to problems. Precise but not accurate (calibration error), Pareto for prioritization, Rule of Seven for early detection, Statistical Sampling for cost-effective inspection. Expert-level quality management.

medium.text: Good understanding of quality tools. Review one or two: Pareto vs Control Chart distinction, or Rule of Seven application.

low.text: Quality tools aren't interchangeable. Each solves specific problem. Study: Pareto (prioritize), Control Chart (monitor stability), Statistical Sampling (cost-effective inspection), Accuracy vs Precision (calibration).

screens.title: Software Defects Crisis
screens.context: Savory's mobile app launched. Within 48 hours, customers report bugs: crashes, wrong orders, payment failures. Taylor (Tech Lead): 'We tested before launch—why so many bugs now?' Jordan: 'Should have used Continuous Integration. Testing once isn't enough for frequent code changes. Need to test CONTINUOUSLY during development.'

options.text: Testing and integrating code FREQUENTLY (daily or multiple times/day)
Hiring more testers at the end

feedback.correct: Correct! CI tests and integrates code FREQUENTLY (daily+) to catch bugs IMMEDIATELY before they compound. This is Quality ASSURANCE (prevention), not just end testing (detection).
feedback.incorrect: Continuous Integration = Testing and integrating code FREQUENTLY (daily or more) during development. Catches bugs early before they compound with other changes.

questions.question: How does CI prevent bugs from accumulating?

options.text: Catches all bugs before any coding starts
Bugs caught IMMEDIATELY before they compound with other code changes

feedback.correct: Perfect! CI catches bugs EARLY (immediately after code changes) before they compound. Early fixes are cheaper than late fixes.
feedback.incorrect: CI catches bugs IMMEDIATELY after code changes, before they compound with other changes. Early detection = easier/cheaper fixes.

questions.question: Classify CI as QA or QC:

feedback.correct: Excellent! CI is Quality ASSURANCE (prevention)—prevents bugs from accumulating by testing continuously DURING development. Not just end detection (QC).
feedback.incorrect: CI is Quality ASSURANCE (prevention throughout development), not Quality CONTROL (detection at end). CI prevents bugs from accumulating by testing continuously.

screens.title: Quality Management Mastery
screens.summary: You've learned to match quality tools to problems and distinguish QA (prevention) from QC (detection). Use Pareto Charts to prioritize (80/20 rule), Control Charts to monitor stability (Rule of Seven), Statistical Sampling for cost-effective inspection, and CI for software quality. QA prevents defects (training, process improvement). QC detects defects (inspection, testing). Both necessary, but PMI emphasizes prevention as more cost-effective.
takeaways: Quality Assurance (QA) = Defect prevention (training, process improvement, CI). Quality Control (QC) = Defect detection (inspection, testing). QA is proactive, QC is reactive.
Pareto Chart prioritizes defects (80/20 rule—vital few vs trivial many). Control Chart monitors stability (Rule of Seven: 7+ consecutive on one side = investigate)
Statistical Sampling inspects subset to predict overall quality—cost-effective alternative to 100% inspection (RANDOM sampling required)
Accuracy vs Precision: Accuracy = close to target. Precision = consistent with each other. Can be precise without accurate (systematic bias)
Quality vs Grade: Low grade (budget) acceptable if meets requirements. Low quality (defects) NEVER acceptable regardless of grade
Continuous Integration (CI) is QA (prevention throughout development), not QC (detection at end)
